metadata.titleEn: Early Cretaceous volcanic rock data set in northern North China
metadata.description: The data include major elements, trace elements and Sr – nd Pb isotopic data. In 2018, samples were collected from the early Cretaceous Chaoyang and Beipiao volcanic rocks in the northern North China Craton. The whole rock major geochemical data were obtained by rigaku-zsx-100e X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF). The whole rock trace geochemical data were obtained by Perkin Elmer Elan 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The whole rock SR – nd Pb isotopic compositions were obtained by sample separation and purification and multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The data obtained can reveal the contribution of mantle and crustal melt to basic to intermediate acid volcanic rocks, and evaluate the importance of mantle derived magma underplating to the formation and evolution of continental crust in post collisional environment.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "wrmt. Xlsx" represents the whole rock master and trace data. The file name "wriso. Xlsx" represents the whole rock isotopic geochemical data.

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Petrological and Geochemical Constraints on the Origin of Early Cretaceous Volcanic Rocks in the Central-East Asia: Implications for Crustal Growth and Evolution

Petrological and Geochemical Constraints on the Origin of Early Cretaceous Volcanic Rocks in the Central‐East Asia: Implications for Crustal Growth and Evolution. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 19(9), 3004-3018.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features and techniques involved in collecting geochemical and isotopic data from early Cretaceous volcanic rocks in Northern North China?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock major element geochemical data, Rigaku-ZSX-100e X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, whole-rock trace element geochemical data, Perkin Elmer ELAN 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer, whole-rock Sr–Nd-Pb isotopic data, multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer

Quantification.Question: How many samples were collected from the Northern North China Craton region for the Early Cretaceous volcanic rocks?
Quantification.Answer: The original answer does not provide a specific numerical value for the number of samples collected. Therefore, there is no quantifiable information to extract or refine.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry enhance the interpretation of volcanic rock geochemistry and isotope data?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of X-ray fluorescence spectrometry provides comprehensive major element geochemical data, while inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry offers detailed trace element analysis. Multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry allows for precise isotope measurements. Together, these methods enable a detailed understanding of mantle and crustal contributions to volcanic rock composition, and help assess the significance of mantle-derived magma underplating in post-collisional continental crust formation and evolution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes might contribute to variations or inaccuracies in geochemical data collection methods, particularly when analyzing early Cretaceous volcanic rocks in North China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations or inaccuracies in geochemical data collection methods could be attributed to several factors, including the precision and calibration of the instruments used, such as the Rigaku-ZSX-100e X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) and the Perkin Elmer ELAN 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). Additionally, the sample preparation process, the condition and preservation of the volcanic rock samples collected from North China, and potential human error during sample handling and analysis could also contribute to these variations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting volcanic rock data such as whole-rock major elements, trace elements, and isotope data from the Early Cretaceous volcanic rocks in northern North China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting volcanic rock data, including whole-rock major elements, trace elements, and isotope data, is to reveal the contributions of mantle and crustal melts to the formation of basic to intermediate-acidic volcanic rocks and to evaluate the significance of mantle-derived magmatic underplating in the formation and evolution of continental crust in a post-collisional setting.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of geochemical data when using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for analyzing volcanic rock samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the field mentioned, geochemical data for volcanic rock samples are obtained using a Rigaku-ZSX-100e X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) for whole-rock major elements and a Perkin Elmer ELAN 6000 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) for whole-rock trace elements. Ensuring accuracy and reliability involves meticulous sample preparation, calibration against known standards, and possibly repeated measurements to account for instrument variability.
